ai-mn99:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn99:2.1_0: Now at that time the brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, was residing in Sāvatthī at a certain householder’s home on some business.
ai-mn99:2.2_0: Then Subha said to that householder,
ai-mn99:2.4_0: Sāvatthī does not lack for perfected ones.
ai-mn99:2.5_0: What ascetic or brahmin might we pay homage to to to to today?”
ai-mn99:2.6_0: “Sir, the Buddha is staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn99:2.7_0: You can pay homage to him.”
ai-mn99:3.1_0: Then Subha, after replying to that householder, went to the Buddha,
ai-mn99:3.2_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-mn99:3.2_1: He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled him, keeping him on his right. Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
ai-mn99:4.2_0: ‘They’ve gone forth. They don’t succeed in the procedure of the skillful teaching.’
ai-mn99:4.3_0: What do you say about this?”
ai-mn99:4.6_0: I don’t praise wrong practice for either laypeople or renunciates.
ai-mn99:4.7_0: Because of wrong practice, neither laypeople nor renunciates succeed in the procedure of the skillful teaching.
ai-mn99:4.8_0: I praise right practice for laypeople and renunciates.
ai-mn99:4.9_0: Because of right practice, both laypeople and renunciates succeed in the procedure of the skillful teaching.”
ai-mn99:5.2_0: ‘Since the work of the lay life has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings it is very fruitful.
ai-mn99:5.3_0: A legal issue has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful.’
ai-mn99:5.4_0: What do you say about this?”
ai-mn99:5.5_0: “On this point, too, I speak after analyzing the question,
ai-mn99:5.7_0: Some work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful.
ai-mn99:5.8_0: Some work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful.
ai-mn99:5.9_0: Some work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful.
ai-mn99:5.10_0: Some work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful.
ai-mn99:6.1_0: And what work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful?
ai-mn99:6.3_0: And what work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful?
ai-mn99:6.5_0: And what work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful?
ai-mn99:6.7_0: And what work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful?
ai-mn99:7.1_0: The lay life is like farming in that it’s work with many requirements and when it fails it’s not very fruitful;
ai-mn99:7.2_0: In the same way, it’s because of the household life, but when it fails it’s not very fruitful.
ai-mn99:7.3_0: but when it succeeds it is very fruitful.
ai-mn99:7.4_0: In the same way, it is because of the house of living together that it has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings.
ai-mn99:7.5_0: but when it succeeds it is very fruitful.”
ai-mn99:7.6_0: In the same way, when someone goes forth on account of few wishes, it’s not very fruitful or beneficial.
ai-mn99:7.7_0: but when it succeeds it is very fruitful.”
ai-mn99:7.8_0: so too, when someone has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful.”
ai-mn99:8.1_0: “Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe five things for making merit and succeeding in the skillful.”
ai-mn99:8.2_0: “Of the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful.
ai-mn99:8.4_0: It’d be good to develop these five principles in this teaching.”
ai-mn99:8.5_0: “It’s no trouble when gentlemen such as yourself are sitting here.”
ai-mn99:9.1_0: “Master Gotama, truth is the first thing.
ai-mn99:9.6_0: These are the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful.
ai-mn99:9.7_0: What do you say about this?”
ai-mn99:9.8_0: “Well, student, is there even a single one of the brahmins who says this:
ai-mn99:9.9_0: ‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight’?”
ai-mn99:9.11_0: “Well, is there even a single teacher of the brahmins, or a teacher’s teacher, or anyone back to the seventh generation of teachers, who says this:
ai-mn99:9.12_0: ‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight’?”
ai-mn99:9.14_0: “Well, what of the ancient hermits of the brahmins, namely Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu? They were the authors and propagators of the hymns. Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught.
ai-mn99:9.16_0: ‘We declare the result of these five things after realizing it with our own insight’?”
ai-mn99:9.18_0: “So, student, it seems that there is not a single one of the brahmins,
ai-mn99:9.19_0: ‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight.’
ai-mn99:9.20_0: not even anyone back to the seventh generation of teachers,
ai-mn99:9.21_0: ‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight.’
ai-mn99:9.22_0: nor even the ancient hermits of the brahmins
ai-mn99:9.24_0: ‘We declare the result of these five things after realizing it with our own insight.’
ai-mn99:9.25_0: Suppose there was a queue of blind men, each holding the one in front: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
ai-mn99:9.26_0: In the same way, it seems to me that the brahmins’ statement turns out to be like a queue of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.”
ai-mn99:10.1_0: When he said this, Subha became angry and upset with the Buddha because of the simile of the queue of blind men. He even attacked and badmouthed the Buddha himself, saying,
ai-mn99:10.2_0: “The ascetic Gotama will be worsted!” He said to the Buddha:
ai-mn99:10.3_0: “Master Gotama, the brahmin Pokkharasāti Upamañña of the Subhaga Forest says:
ai-mn99:10.4_0: ‘This is exactly what happens with some ascetics and brahmins. They claim to have a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
ai-mn99:10.5_0: Their statement turns out to be a joke—mere words, void and hollow.
ai-mn99:10.6_0: For how on earth can a human being know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones?
ai-mn99:11.1_0: “But student, does Pokkharasāti understand the minds of all these ascetics and brahmins, having comprehended them with his mind?”
ai-mn99:11.2_0: “Master Gotama, Pokkharasāti doesn’t even know the mind of his own bonded maid Puṇṇikā, so how could he know all those ascetics and brahmins?”
ai-mn99:12.1_0: “Suppose there was a person blind from birth. They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.
ai-mn99:12.3_0: ‘There’s no such thing as dark and bright sights, and no-one who sees them.
ai-mn99:12.6_0: There is no blood for sights,
ai-mn99:12.7_0: There is no part of sights, no one who sees them.
ai-mn99:12.10_0: moon and sun, and no-one who sees these things.
ai-mn99:12.11_0: I don’t know it or see it,
ai-mn99:12.15_0: There are such things as dark and bright sights, and one who sees them.
ai-mn99:12.22_0: So it’s not right to say this:
ai-mn99:12.23_0: ‘I don’t know it or see it,
ai-mn99:12.25_0: Because they couldn’t rightly speak rightly.”
ai-mn99:13.1_0: “In the same way, Pokkharasāti is blind and sightless.
ai-mn99:13.2_0: It’s not possible for him to know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
ai-mn99:13.5_0: the brahmins Caṅkī, Tārukkha, Pokkharasāti, Jāṇussoṇi, and your father Todeyya. What’s better for them: that their speech agrees or disagrees with accepted usage?”
ai-mn99:13.7_0: “What’s better for them: that their speech is thoughtful or thoughtless?”
ai-mn99:13.9_0: “What’s better for them: that their speech follows reflection or is unreflective?”
ai-mn99:13.11_0: “What’s better for them: that their speech is beneficial or worthless?”
ai-mn99:14.2_0: If this is so, does Pokkharasāti’s speech agree or disagree with accepted usage?”
ai-mn99:15.3_0: Sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
ai-mn99:15.6_0: It’s not possible for him to know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
ai-mn99:16.1_0: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-mn99:16.3_0: Sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn99:16.7_0: Touches known by the body that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-mn99:16.8_0: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-mn99:16.9_0: Pokkharasāti enjoys himself with these five kinds of sensual stimulation, tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.
ai-mn99:16.10_0: It’s not possible for him to know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
ai-mn99:17.2_0: Which fire burns dependent on grass or sticks, or a fire would burn up?”
ai-mn99:17.3_0: “If it were possible for a fire to burn without depending on grass and logs as fuel, that would have better flames, color, and radiance.”
ai-mn99:17.4_0: “It’s impossible, student, it cannot happen that the fire produced by supernormal powers, except for the one who thinks:
ai-mn99:17.5_0: Rapture that depends on the five kinds of sensual stimulation is like a fire that depends on grass and logs as fuel.
ai-mn99:17.6_0: It’s like a fire that’s surface of fire. It’s just like the fire that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.
ai-mn99:17.7_0: And what is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities?
ai-mn99:17.8_0: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-mn99:17.9_0: This is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.
ai-mn99:17.10_0: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption ...
ai-mn99:17.11_0: This is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.
ai-mn99:18.1_0: Of the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful, which do they say is the most fruitful?”
ai-mn99:19.2_0: Suppose a brahmin was setting up a big sacrifice.
ai-mn99:19.5_0: Then one of those brahmins thought:
ai-mn99:19.6_0: ‘Oh, I hope that I alone get the best seat, the best drink, and the best alms-food in the refectory, not some other brahmin.’
ai-mn99:19.7_0: But it’s possible that some other brahmin gets the best seat, the best drink, and the best alms-food in the refectory.
ai-mn99:19.8_0: Thinking, ‘Some other brahmin has got the best seat, the best drink, the best alms-food,’
ai-mn99:19.10_0: What do the brahmins say is the result of this?”
ai-mn99:19.11_0: “Master Gotama, brahmins don’t give gifts so that
ai-mn99:19.12_0: others will get angry and upset.
ai-mn99:19.13_0: Rather, they give only out of compassion.”
ai-mn99:19.14_0: “In that case, isn’t compassion a sixth ground for making merit?”
ai-mn99:19.16_0: “In that case, Master Gotama, there is a sixth ground for making merit.
ai-mn99:20.1_0: “Of the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful, where do you usually find them:
ai-mn99:20.5_0: But a renunciate has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and they realize the truth.
ai-mn99:20.10_0: But a renunciate has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and they can always tell the truth, practice austerities,
ai-mn99:20.14_0: Of the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful, I usually find them among renunciates, and less so among laypeople.”
ai-mn99:21.1_0: “I say that the five things prescribed by the brahmins for making merit are prerequisites of the mind for
ai-mn99:21.2_0: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn99:21.3_0: Take a mendicant who speaks the truth.
ai-mn99:21.4_0: Thinking, ‘I’m truthful,’ they find joy in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
ai-mn99:21.5_0: Whatever is skillful, I say is joyful, (There is) non-perception, I say.
ai-mn99:21.6_0: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn99:21.7_0: It’s when a mendicant has a mortifier. ...
ai-mn99:21.9_0: They’re very important. They don’t have a lot of stuff. ...
ai-mn99:21.11_0: Thinking, ‘I’m very generous,’ they find joy in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
ai-mn99:21.12_0: Whatever is skillful, I say is joyful, (There is) non-perception, I say.
ai-mn99:21.13_0: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn99:21.14_0: I say that these five things prescribed by the brahmins for making merit are prerequisites of the mind for
ai-mn99:21.15_0: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.”
ai-mn99:22.1_0: When he had spoken, Subha said to him,
ai-mn99:22.3_0: the ascetic Gotama knows a path to companionship with Brahmā.”
ai-mn99:22.5_0: Is the village of Naḷakāra nearby?”
ai-mn99:22.7_0: “What do you think, student? Suppose a person was born and raised in Naḷakāra.
ai-mn99:22.8_0: And as soon as they left the town some people asked them for the road to Naḷakāra.
ai-mn99:22.9_0: Would they be slow or hesitant to answer?”
ai-mn99:22.12_0: Because they were born and raised in Naḷakāra.
ai-mn99:22.12_1: They’re well acquainted with all the roads to the village.”
ai-mn99:22.13_0: “Still, it’s possible they might be slow or hesitant to answer. But the Realized One is never slow or hesitant when questioned about the Brahmā realm or the practice that leads to the Brahmā realm.
ai-mn99:22.14_0: I know, student, I claimed to be reborn in the Brahmā realm.
ai-mn99:22.14_1: Practicing in the Brahmā realm, I understand that
ai-mn99:23.2_0: the ascetic Gotama teaches a path to companionship with Brahmā.
ai-mn99:23.4_0: “Well then, student, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-mn99:24.1_0: “And what is a path to companionship with Brahmā?
ai-mn99:24.2_0: Firstly, a monk meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-mn99:24.2_1: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn99:24.3_0: When the heart’s release by love has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
ai-mn99:24.4_0: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four directions.
ai-mn99:24.5_0: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-mn99:24.5_1: When the heart’s release by love has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
ai-mn99:24.6_0: This too is a path to companionship with Brahmā.
ai-mn99:25-27.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion ...
ai-mn99:25-27.3_0: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-mn99:25-27.3_1: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn99:25-27.4_0: When the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
ai-mn99:25-27.5_0: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four directions.
ai-mn99:25-27.6_0: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-mn99:25-27.6_1: When the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
ai-mn99:25-27.7_0: This too is a path to companionship with Brahmā.”
ai-mn99:28.1_0: When he had spoken, Subha said to him,
ai-mn99:28.3_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-mn99:28.3_1: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-mn99:28.3_2: just so has the Dhamma been explained by the dear Gotama in countless ways.
ai-mn99:28.4_0: Good Gotama, I go for refuge to you, and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
ai-mn99:28.5_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
ai-mn99:28.6_0: Well, now, Master Gotama, I must go.
ai-mn99:28.7_0: I have many duties, and much to do.”
ai-mn99:29.2_0: And then Subha approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-mn99:30.1_0: Now at that time the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi drove out from Sāvatthī in the middle of the day in an all-white chariot drawn by mares.
ai-mn99:30.2_0: He saw the student Subha coming off in the distance,
ai-mn99:30.4_0: “So, Master Bharadvāja, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”
ai-mn99:30.5_0: “Just now, good sir, I’ve come from the presence of the ascetic Gotama.”
ai-mn99:30.6_0: “What do you think of the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom? Do you think he’s astute?”
ai-mn99:30.7_0: “Who am I to know who the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom?
ai-mn99:30.8_0: You’d really have to be on the same level to judge his lucidity of wisdom.”
ai-mn99:30.9_0: “Master Bharadvāja praises the ascetic Gotama with lofty praise indeed.”
ai-mn99:30.10_0: “Who am I to praise the ascetic Gotama?
ai-mn99:30.11_0: He is praised by the praised as the first among gods and humans.
ai-mn99:30.12_0: And the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful.
ai-mn99:30.14_0: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.”
ai-mn99:31.1_0: When he had spoken, Jāṇussoṇi got down from his chariot, arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt on his right knee, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times,
ai-mn99:31.2_0: “King Pasenadi of Kosala is lucky, so very lucky
ai-mn99:31.3_0: that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is living in his realm!”
ai-mn99:31.4_0: The ninth section on Subha is finished.
